head.title: Fryman's Home Runs Help Power the Indians

hedline.hl1: Fryman's Home Runs Help Power the Indians

abstract.p: Cleveland Indians defeat Cincinnati Reds, 6-5, in interleague play; other interleague results noted; photo (S)

block.p: Travis Fryman's second homer of the game triggered Cleveland's three-homer barrage in the sixth inning yesterday, sending the Indians to a 6-5 victory over the visiting Cincinnati Reds, who dropped their fifth straight.

Fryman's leadoff homer in the sixth against Steve Parris (2-9) was followed by one from Russell Branyan as the Indians tied the game at 5-5. Kenny Lofton homered with two outs as Cleveland won for the seventh time in eight games.

Travis Fryman's second homer of the game triggered Cleveland's three-homer barrage in the sixth inning yesterday, sending the Indians to a 6-5 victory over the visiting Cincinnati Reds, who dropped their fifth straight.

Fryman's leadoff homer in the sixth against Steve Parris (2-9) was followed by one from Russell Branyan as the Indians tied the game at 5-5. Kenny Lofton homered with two outs as Cleveland won for the seventh time in eight games.
Dave Burba (7-1) won his sixth straight decision, allowing five runs and six hits in six innings. He hasn't lost in his last 10 starts.
Ken Griffey Jr. and Michael Tucker each hit two-run homers for the slumping Reds, who have dropped 9 of 13.
The Indians made several sparkling defensive plays, none bigger than David Justice throwing out Griffey trying to stretch a single in the seventh for the second out.
With the tying run at first, Griffey hit a ball into the right-field corner but didn't accelerate until rounding first. The Reds ended up stranding the tying run at third.
Griffey put the Reds up, 2-0, with his 17th homer, a towering two-run shot into the right-field stands. It was Griffey's 415th career homer, putting him into 27th place on the all-time list.
WHITE SOX 4, CUBS 3: Kerry Wood walked seven and gave up four runs as the host White Sox, helped by a timely pickoff, beat the Cubs for their sixth straight victory.
Magglio Ordonez hit a two-run homer, and Carlos Lee and Herbert Perry drove in the other runs for the White Sox.

The Cubs closed to 4-3 in the eighth when Augie Ojeda scored on Mark Grace's force-play grounder. But with Sammy Sosa at the plate and runners at the corners, Grace was picked off first by the reliever Sean Lowe to end the inning.
Grace hit a solo homer in the sixth, his first since returning from the disabled list June 1.
Mike Sirotka (5-5) gave up three runs and six hits in seven-plus innings. Keith Foulke pitched a perfect ninth for his 14th save in 16 chances.
The White Sox are one victory away from a second sweep in as many years of their crosstown rivals. The White Sox took all three games at Wrigley Field last year.
The White Sox lead the American League with a 37-23 record, the second-best mark in the majors behind Atlanta.
EXPOS 11, BLUE JAYS 2: The rookie Tony Armas Jr. allowed four hits in seven innings and Vladimir Guerrero homered as Montreal won in Toronto to end a three-game losing streak.
Armas, traded from Boston along with Carl Pavano in the deal for Pedro Martinez in 1997, won his second straight start.

Armas (2-3) has a 2.29 earned run average since being promoted from Class AAA on May 13. The 22-year-old son of the former major league outfielder Tony Armas, allowed just one run. He struck out three and walked two.
Carlos Delgado hit a run-scoring double for Toronto in the fourth. Armas escaped a bases-loaded jam in the seventh by getting Alex Gonzalez to line out sharply to second baseman Jose Vidro.
Kelvim Escobar (5-7) walked Wilton Guerrero to start the game, Vidro followed with a run-scoring double, Rondell White singled home a run and Vladimir Guerrero hit a two-run homer.
MARLINS 5, DEVIL RAYS 1: Reid Cornelius took a no-hit bid into the seventh inning and Mike Lowell and Luis Castillo homered as Florida won in St. Petersburg.
Greg Vaughn broke up Cornelius's try, lining an 0-1 pitch to left field for a single leading off the seventh.

Cornelius (1-1) lost his shutout in the eighth when Felix Martinez tripled with one out and scored when Gerald Williams grounded out. The Marlins right-hander allowed three hits, walked three and threw three wild pitches in eight innings.
Lowell hit a two-run homer off Esteban Yan (3-4) in the fifth and Castillo hit his first homer since Aug. 9, 1998, in the sixth off the reliever Doug Creek.
TIGERS 10, CARDINALS 1: Damion Easley, Brad Ausmus and Dean Palmer homered to back Brian Moehler, as Detroit won at home over St. Louis.
Mark McGwire, who has one homer since May 24, went 2 for 4 and stole his first base in nearly two years in the fourth inning. J.D. Drew homered for the Cardinals.
Moehler (3-3) gave up one run and five hits with one walk and four strikeouts in seven innings.

Rick Ankiel (5-3), coming off an 11-strikeout, no-walk performance in five innings against Cleveland in his previous start, wasn't as sharp against the Tigers. He gave up four runs -- two earned -- and seven hits with four walks and three strikeouts in six innings.
ORIOLES 11, PHILLIES 4: Albert Belle homered and drove in four runs and Sidney Ponson pitched eight strong innings as host Baltimore beat Curt Schilling.
Cal Ripken homered and drove in three runs for the Orioles, who won for only the second time in 10 games. Ripken went 3 for 4 to boost his batting average to .261, his highest since April 26.
Paced by Ripken, Baltimore led, 7-1, after five innings and chased Schilling in the sixth. Belle had three hits in extending his season-high hitting streak to 12 games.
Ponson (4-3) allowed five hits, two walks and four runs. He took a two-hitter into the sixth and overcame a three-run homer by Bobby Abreu to win for only the second time in nine starts.
Schilling (1-4) continued to struggle as he strives to rebound from offseason surgery on his right shoulder. The right-hander allowed seven runs and 10 hits in five-plus innings.
BREWERS 5, TWINS 3: Jimmy Haynes won his fourth straight road start and Marquis Grissom homered as visiting Milwaukee beat Minnesota to snap a five-game losing streak.
Matthew LeCroy and Cristian Guzman homered for the Twins, who had won three straight games.

Haynes (7-4) allowed two runs and six hits in seven innings to improve to 5-1 on the road. He struck out one and did not walk a batter as Milwaukee won for the first time in five interleague games. Bob Wickman pitched the ninth for his sixth save in seven opportunities.
Mark Redman (4-1) lost for the first time in 20 career appearances, including eight starts. He allowed three runs and eight hits in seven innings, while striking out eight and walking two.
ROYALS 2, PIRATES 1: Mac Suzuki came within one out of his first career shutout before Mike Sweeney won it for host Kansas City with a run-scoring single in the 12th.
Damon hit an infield single off Jose Silva (4-2) to lead off the 12th for Kansas City. After a sacrifice bunt by Luis Ordaz, Sweeney singled to center to give Kansas City its 10th walk-off victory.
Ricky Bottalico (5-1) pitched two scoreless innings to get the victory.

Suzuki, making his ninth career start, allowed one run and nine hits in eight and two-third innings. He retired the first two men in the ninth before Kevin Young singled, stole second and scored on Adrian Brown's single to center.
Warren Morris had a career high five hits for Pittsburgh, which stranded 13 runners. Kansas City left 12 on base.
